results.title: Qesa: stories from the Craig Family Centre
results.brief_description: The African nation of Sudan has suffered the longest periods of sustained civil war in history. In this compilation of digital stories, women from North and South Sudan recount their experience of war, migration and settlement in Australia.

results.title: Human remains
results.brief_description: Human Remains reviews the eccentricities of the 20th century’s most reviled dictators (Hitler, Stalin, Mao, Franco, Mussolini).

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 09
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for and broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie and co-presenter Lena Corner roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode: Firstly at RMIT Project Space is the group exhibition by artists Peta Clancy, Sylvia Kranawetvogl, Erik Hable and James Cecil called “Body Manufacture”, an exhibition in response to the 1974 discovery in geneology of the chromosome. The exhibition seeks to explore the ‘sexing’ of scientific imagery and the publics’ relationship to images of the intangible and abstract. At Mira Gallery, James Meldrum talks about his practice and ‘letting go..’ and the NGV hosts another year of ‘Top Arts’, an exhibition of Victoria’s top art folio’s submitted by Year 12 VCE students. Screen Talk this episode focuses on Media Art Graduate work: Joel Zika’s ‘In the woods’ is a sombre abstraction with a soundscape that brings our ears close to the ground with elements reminiscent of Len Lye’s kinetic metal sculptures. Anne Perri’s ‘The Erotica shakes me’ is a play on the banality of neon signs and the desire to construct meaning. ‘On the way home’ by Isobel and Jeremy digitally constructs silhoutted imagery in a style made famous by Lotte Reiniger.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 07
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for and broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie again surprises us with a taste of the local art scene. Lucas Ilhein with ‘Found Project Space’ locate themselves on the banks of the Yarra next to the “yellow peril” in a performance piece that plays on interaction, racial stereotypes, self-deprecation and a healthy t-shirt business. At Gasworks Arts Inc. Louisanne Zahra walks us through her site-specific exhibition installed within the theatre. The delicate and intricate works borrow much from the 19th Century and explorations in themes of nature and collections. Monash University Gallery has both a collaborative exhibition of Australian and Thailand artists and ‘Taring Padi’, a show of Indonesian artists from the artists collective of the same name. Interviewed is Stuart Koop (curator), Jane Trengrove (artist) and Michael Shaowanasai (artist) amongst others. The irreverent artist Guy Benfield is featured as this episode’s video artist discussing his motives behind his practice and humorous video works and performances. Featured are excerpts from his video works ‘Spacewalk(work out)’, ‘Hiace Van’ and ‘French Pup (live action)’.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 13
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode, Andrew MacKenzie presents a show of his favourite bits from the first series. This includes: The opening of the Helen Lempriere National Sculpture Prize, ‘Neo Noir’ at Gertrude Contemporary Art Spaces, ‘Art Bites’ community project in Parkdale, ‘Comic Book Lifestyle’ Linden St Kilda Centre for Contemporary Arts, Sticky - the comic book shop and James Meldrum at Mira Gallery.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 01
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie is there for the announcement of the winner to the second Helen Lempriere National Sculpture Award at Werribee Park. Andrew speaks with contestants and judges including Inge King. At Gammaspace, an art auction to raise funds for the Easter protests at Woomera is covered and at the Centre for Contemporary Photography (CCP) the witty and playful collaborators Nat and Ali present their work the ‘Art Bar’. A performance/installation piece that explores celebrity, art politics, art and the alcoholic muse.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 01
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie introduces a packed program. Tim Danko curates at Westspace “Paper Skin - Constructed Guts” an exhibition of the work of thirty contemporary local and overseas comic book producers/artists. Brendan Tolley, Kirrily Schell and Cassandra Tytler are a few of the artists. Nat & Ali provide more comic relief with their lived-in performance on opening night. At Linden St Kilda Contemporary Arts is ‘High Tide’, a photographic exhibition by contemporary indigenous artists looking at the landscape. Curated by Christian Thompson the artists include; Destiny Deacon, Brenda Croft, Michael Riley, Jenny Fraser, Jason Hampton and Dianne Jones. An excerpt of Michael Riley’s film ‘Empire’ is included with music by Anthony Parthos performed by the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra (first screened on ABC 2000). At Ian Potter Museum of Art ‘It’s a Beautiful Day’ opens. An exhibition exploring the gamut of contemporary painting that includes the work of Peter Booth, Brent Harris, Vivien Shark le Wit, Anne Wallace and David Jolly to name a few. Curated by Bala Starr.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 11
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Lena Corner interviews Sue Wyers in her studio and talks about the ‘honoured object’ and ‘domains of defiance’, themes related to Wyers’ work. Rod Quantock is the talking head at Span Galleries opening of the ‘Artful Dodgers’ revealing the Xena photographs as his favourite. RMIT gallery opens its retrospective of internationally renowned German artist, Gerhard Richter. The exhibition surveys forty years of Richter’s work using examples that identify ‘touchstones’ for the artist as selected by Richter himself. The works explore the fluid line between the abstract and figurative and use process both as a means and an end. The exhibition at Westspace Gating” is a group show exploring sound technologies. Featured are the works by Michael Graeve, Simon Kilvert (Decent Column), Rhino Lintz and Mark [Marco] Fusinato (2’ 30”). Screen Talk this week features Leslie Eastman whose work is concerned with exploring themes such as; language and time, the objectivity of language and its phenomenon versus conditional experience.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 10
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Lena Corner rounds up the mood of the Next Wave Festival opening to then look at the collaborative community project from the program ‘Moving Along’ and the performance of ‘The Angels’ who took up residency on Melbourne’s State Theatre spire for a ten day period whilst doing performances on the spire over that time. ‘Neo Noir’ curated by Mark Feary opens at Gertrude Contemporary Art Space with artists; Sharon Goodwin, Matthew Griffin, Amanda Marburg, Kate Just, Sarah Lynch, Camilla Hannan, Van Sowerwine. Three works at CCP are investigated; ‘Play With Me’, ‘Skin Club’ and ‘Solid Estate’. This week’s Screen Talk features the work ‘Human machine landscape’ by Simon Price and Simon Terrill shown at Fortyfivedownstairs.

In this episode Lena Corner rounds up the mood of the Next Wave Festival opening to then look at the collaborative community project from the program ‘Moving Along’ and the performance of ‘The Angels’ who took up residency on Melbourne’s State Theatre spire for a ten day period whilst doing performances on the spire over that time. ‘Neo Noir’ curated by Mark Feary opens at Gertrude Contemporary Art Space with artists; Sharon Goodwin, Matthew Griffin, Amanda Marburg, Kate Just, Sarah Lynch, Camilla Hannan, Van Sowerwine. Three works at CCP are investigated; ‘Play With Me’, ‘Skin Club’ and ‘Solid Estate’. This week’s Screen Talk features the work ‘Human machine landscape’ by Simon Price and Simon Terrill shown at Fortyfivedownstairs.
description_for_label:
Episode number 10 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Lena Corner rounds up the mood of the Next Wave Festival opening to then look at the collaborative community project from the program ‘Moving Along’ and the performance of ‘The Angels’ who took up residency on Melbourne’s State Theatre spire for a ten day period whilst doing performances on the spire over that time. ‘Neo Noir’ curated by Mark Feary opens at Gertrude Contemporary Art Space with artists; Sharon Goodwin, Matthew Griffin, Amanda Marburg, Kate Just, Sarah Lynch, Camilla Hannan, Van Sowerwine. Three works at CCP are investigated; ‘Play With Me’, ‘Skin Club’ and ‘Solid Estate’. This week’s Screen Talk features the work ‘Human machine landscape’ by Simon Price and Simon Terrill shown at Fortyfivedownstairs.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 02
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The programs style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode the roving presenter Andrew MacKenzie provides a glimpse into a hectic week in the Melbourne art scene. Melbourne Fashion Week hosts a number of exhibitions around Melbourne. Interviewed are: Lyndal Jones (Australia’s representative at the 2000 Venice Biennale), from Munich the collaborative ‘Chicks On Speed’ present work at Westspace, Akira Isogawa has his first solo exhibition at RMIT showcasing his passionate exploration of textiles and Peter Robertson explores through photographs the uniquely Melbourne ‘Sharpies’ sub-culture of the 1970’s. A culture that unlike the ‘Skins’ blended style with thuggery whilst even having a dance style all to their own. Also featured are: Local graffiti artists in Flinders Lane, ‘Exploration 3’ at Flinders Lane Gallery and Bus Gallery also get a look in. Louise Hubbard is interviewed
